New issue

Connection leakage when inspecting exceptions across Threads #19332

Open
halorgium opened this Issue Mar 14, 2015 · 10 comments

Labels

None yet

Milestone

No milestone

Assignee

No one assigned

5 participants

halorgium commented Mar 14, 2015

We've been tracking an issue with Celluloid (celluloid/celluloid#499) where an exception occurs inside ActiveRecord and is then handled by the core Celluloid actor as a crash.
As part of the handling, the exception is inspected which causes a connection to be checked out of the pool. Then the thread dies and orphans the connection.

Was the assumption around .inspect (and .table_exists?) that these methods would be used inside Threads which already hold a checked-out connection?
In Celluloid, we run blocks of code inside separate Threads or Fibers to allow for pipelining and suspending. Because of this, any methods which only checkout connections are prone to leakage.

Is this change an acceptable one? halorgium@8599bf2
I note that many other methods are along a similar vein.

/cc @tarcieri @nullstyle

halorgium commented Mar 14, 2015

I have distilled the issue to a simpler repro: https://gist.github.com/halorgium/2778b0db4286b907343a

Owner
matthewd commented Mar 14, 2015

Which Rails version are you using? 4.2 should reclaim the connection shortly after the owning thread dies.

That commit seems fine.. though as we are currently pretty free with our use of connection, I'm not sure whether I'd consider it a back-portable bug fix.

tarcieri commented Mar 14, 2015

@matthewd what sort of mechanism does it use to reclaim them? Celluloid pools threads, as it were...

halorgium commented Mar 14, 2015

@matthewd using 4.2 produces the same result. I am mostly concerned about the thread holding the connection if it does not die.
There is another code path within Celluloid which causes this affect where the core actor thread does not die.

halorgium commented Mar 14, 2015

@tarcieri it is using a #alive? check on the owner thread. 

        stale_connections = synchronize do
          @connections.select do |conn|
            conn.in_use? && !conn.owner.alive?
          end
        end
halorgium commented Mar 14, 2015

@matthewd the other concern is that a simple #inspect on a model can cause a DB connection and query. This seems somewhat excessive, especially if this is called in non-DB threads.
Ideally, a system would not have exceptions, but it does happen and if the result is starving the connection pool, I am ing.

halorgium commented Apr 1, 2015

Is this issue able to get some attention?

TiagoCardoso1983 commented Dec 12, 2015

I've been experiencing issues with AR and Celluloid for like years. I don't if we're all talking about the same issue here, but I have two main issues with AR:

  • touching the ActiveRecord::Base class or anything inheriting it causes the connection to the DB to be established;
  • that each new Fiber task will check out a new connection from the pool, even if a connection has been checked out in the current thread already.

About the first problem, it's quite hard to solve without knowing the AR internals. As for the second, can't we just replace every Thead#[] usage (which creates fiber-local variables) with Thread#thread_variable_get/set? What are the drawbacks? Or has this been discussed elsewhere already?

halorgium commented Dec 14, 2015

@TiagoCardoso1983 the main problem is the assumption that objects (like exceptions) do not often travel between threads. This assumption results in connections being opened (and not closed) in threads which Rails is not managing. The problem is independent of Fibers but is definitely exacerbated.
